09d89fb4-8484-4825-8dea-b82623c20bd5.content: {The theory assumes autonomy requires non-manipulated desires.}, {Manipulated desires compromise a person's ability to set and pursue their own goals.}, {Genuine freedom as autonomy requires desires to originate from the person themselves.}, {A brainwashed person's desires do not originate from themselves, thus they lack autonomy.}

f77daf2e-8a3b-4c0b-9a02-f8c97afcf86b.summary: Freedom as Autonomy with Internal Factors
f77daf2e-8a3b-4c0b-9a02-f8c97afcf86b.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {For a person to be free, their autonomy must not be compromised by internal constraints such as phobias}

a851319a-e3a9-4e56-92d4-2583dd548d31.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {Authentic autonomy requires the absence of psychological constraints like phobias that distort decision-making}

d7435620-0dd9-4aca-94a0-b6e59e7ed9db.summary: Freedom as Autonomy with Rational Reflection
d7435620-0dd9-4aca-94a0-b6e59e7ed9db.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {To be free, a person's autonomy must involve rational reflection and not be overridden by irrational fears}

4e4eec5a-9505-4d3f-8ab9-91eff716c25c.summary: Freedom as Autonomy with Capacity for Rational Choice
4e4eec5a-9505-4d3f-8ab9-91eff716c25c.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {Freedom requires the capacity to make choices uninhibited by unreasonable fears or internal pressures}

80b3ab06-b3a4-406f-87bd-a1a9c5d9b4e7.summary: Freedom as Autonomy Enhanced by Critical Self-reflection
80b3ab06-b3a4-406f-87bd-a1a9c5d9b4e7.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {Autonomy is genuine only when accompanied by critical self-reflection to overcome irrational influences}

a4036f56-f398-4a08-b399-14f6a0e2dadf.summary: Distinguishing between autonomy and psychological constraints
a4036f56-f398-4a08-b399-14f6a0e2dadf.content: {There is a distinction between autonomy and psychological constraints}, {Autonomy focuses on the ability to make self-directed choices without external interference}, {A psychological constraint like a phobia does not negate autonomy if the individual can still engage in self-direction within their capacity}, {The intuition that a phobia negates freedom can be explained by confusing external constraints with internal psychological states}

e16d9b3d-e743-4bbd-91fc-25e7af86241f.summary: Rejecting the intuition that psychological constraints directly negate freedom
e16d9b3d-e743-4bbd-91fc-25e7af86241f.content: {It is mistaken to equate psychological constraints with a lack of autonomy}, {The presence of severe phobias does not inherently remove the capacity for self-governance}, {Freedom as autonomy is about maintaining self-direction despite internal challenges}

bafc7346-cd3a-4e07-b241-63151fbcf2b8.summary: Supplementing autonomy with internal condition awareness
bafc7346-cd3a-4e07-b241-63151fbcf2b8.content: {Awareness of one’s internal psychological conditions, such as phobias, can supplement autonomy}, {Autonomy includes the ability to recognize and work within one's psychological constraints}, {The presence of phobias is not inconsistent with autonomy if the individual can acknowledge and navigate these internal states}

6cdb2229-e5a3-4743-a11d-83ceff49b2f6.content: {Freedom consists in making choices that are reflectively endorsed}, {Reflective endorsement requires critical evaluation of one’s motivations and desires}, {A person is free if their choices align with deeply held values after reflection}

c415b611-4aa7-479b-86a2-6076aa185edd.content: {Freedom requires rational self-governance}, {Rational self-governance involves making decisions based on reason rather than compulsion}, {A person is free if they are able to act according to their rational judgments}

067bef0b-894e-461b-95d8-bedebb98f57c.summary: Freedom as Absence of Coercive Influences
067bef0b-894e-461b-95d8-bedebb98f57c.content: {Freedom consists in the absence of coercive influences on decision-making}, {Coercive influences undermine autonomy by altering decision pathway}, {A person is free if they are not subject to external or internal compulsions leading to undesired actions}

be5ece93-97f2-46fd-ac16-63e2680bafc5.content: {Freedom is the state of ideal self-determination}, {Ideal self-determination involves forming intentions that reflect one’s best interests}, {A person is free if their actions are governed by values they consider ideal}

7f72ae6d-4264-4f6e-84cc-890276414d1e.content: {Freedom consists in making authentic choices}, {Authentic choices are those aligned with one's true desires and values}, {A person is free if their actions stem from honest acknowledgment of their genuine self}

197de4d8-f59c-4789-a584-0cf5f35eacf7.content: {There is a distinction between autonomy and compulsion}, {Freedom as autonomy is a theory about self-directed choice, not about compulsive behaviors}, {An addict's choice to continue usage is compelled by addiction, not autonomously made}, {The intuition that addiction undermines freedom is explained by confusing autonomy with compulsion}

222831b7-9dfa-49bc-ad80-5f44b0dd01c5.summary: Rejecting the intuition that autonomy is present in addiction
222831b7-9dfa-49bc-ad80-5f44b0dd01c5.content: {The intuition that addicts make autonomous choices is mistaken}, {An addict’s decision-making process is significantly impaired by the addiction itself}, {Choices made under the influence of addiction do not reflect true self-governance}

d4405e94-5297-4d43-9a52-596621da30a6.summary: Supplying the concept of hierarchical desires
d4405e94-5297-4d43-9a52-596621da30a6.content: {Desires can be categorized into first-order and second-order desires}, {Autonomy involves acting on second-order desires, where one endorses or rejects first-order desires}, {An addict's inability to align actions with their second-order desire to quit reveals a lack of autonomy}

f27606bf-577a-4907-9545-35ba6fdd9a20.content: {Freedom consists in the absence of constraints from others}, {A person is free if they are not prevented by others from doing what they want}, {Interference by others is the primary limitation on freedom}

3aca2192-66fb-43cb-8eb2-ecb159070297.content: {Freedom requires the absence of arbitrary power by others}, {A person is free if they are not subject to the will of another}, {Non-domination focuses on preventing others from having unchecked control}

60f6c907-f4aa-4696-aae8-852428b9e257.content: {Freedom involves having the genuine ability to achieve one's goals}, {Autonomy includes the presence of necessary resources and opportunities}, {A person is free if they have the capabilities to pursue their chosen ends}

98c2a18b-8986-48dd-811c-e08cbdeb2a10.content: {Freedom is the realization of one's true self and potentials}, {Autonomy is linked to understanding and fulfilling one's nature}, {A person is free if they live in accordance with their true self and potential}

6b1fd710-3320-43f4-a5dc-66bbd0ae3684.content: {Freedom involves acting according to moral laws one has self-endorsed}, {Autonomy is the condition of self-legislation in line with moral principles}, {A person is free if their choices reflect moral self-legislation}

849f99b7-cfd5-4dfe-b594-774f1c16fa17.content: {Freedom consists in acting based on rational deliberation and decision-making}, {Autonomy requires the use of practical reason to make decisions}, {A person is free if their actions are guided by rational understanding}

ba64e0d5-2439-4c56-8ed8-6c029ad07629.content: {Freedom involves having multiple paths and opportunities available}, {Autonomy involves the ability to choose among significant life options}, {A person is free if they have a range of opportunities to pursue}

b45bc48c-613b-48a8-a8f6-e4596c442508.content: {Freedom consists in being empowered to act effectively}, {Autonomy requires having control over one's actions and environment}, {A person is free if they are empowered with the means to achieve their goals}

a658c2b0-6fee-42d3-8ef3-3342dd82aac5.content: {Freedom consists in having control over one's own life circumstances}, {Autonomy involves the capacity to influence one's environment}, {A person is free if they have control to alter their life circumstances}

a2e006e1-ccb4-4f91-a71c-580b4649cf9f.content: {There is a distinction between autonomy as self-governance and the capacity to achieve goals.}, {Freedom as autonomy is a theory about self-governance, not about the ability to overcome external obstacles.}, {External obstacles to achieving goals do not undermine autonomy if they do not affect a person’s capacity to make their own choices.}

1e2549ec-0e41-4098-b39e-467f089b5ebc.summary: Rejecting the intuition that external obstacles limit autonomy
1e2549ec-0e41-4098-b39e-467f089b5ebc.content: {It is mistaken to think that external obstacles impact freedom as autonomy when the ability to make one’s own choices remains intact.}, {Freedom as autonomy remains intact as long as individuals can set their own goals, regardless of external challenges.}, {The intuition that obstacles limit freedom arises from conflating autonomy with external effectiveness.}

ed872afc-e471-4e02-b231-c092b1aff0a5.content: {Freedom as autonomy can be supplemented with the assumption that true freedom includes a reasonable opportunity to pursue one’s goals.}, {External obstacles do not inherently limit autonomy if individuals retain the capacity for self-direction and goal setting.}, {Reasonable opportunities are a separate concern from the self-governing aspect of autonomy.}

7281c469-8c82-4adc-8744-0d4bf86b4823.content: {Freedom consists in having the capability to act on one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves being able to realize self-directed goals}, {A person is free if they have both the ability to set their own goals and the capacity to pursue and achieve them}

b906a952-fd0a-4640-9cb0-6f2cca47f469.content: {Freedom consists in having a range of opportunities to choose from}, {Autonomy involves selecting from genuinely available options}, {A person is free if they can set their own goals and have multiple possible paths to achieve them}

c18a7767-8f0e-4a02-bd5a-85400d3e9743.content: {Freedom consists in being an effective agent in the world}, {Autonomy involves not only making decisions but also the capability to implement them}, {A person is free if they can create plans and have the means to effectively carry them out}

b2cacd7d-2d27-4b12-b072-9ddf8b9c7ff6.content: {Freedom consists in the absence of external impediments to action}, {Autonomy involves having internal sovereignty over decision-making}, {A person is free if they can autonomously set goals and there are no external barriers preventing the pursuit of these goals}

48fea323-8bb1-48a7-a2e8-00c9f97f8d6e.summary: Distinguishing between internal and external freedom
48fea323-8bb1-48a7-a2e8-00c9f97f8d6e.content: {There is a distinction between internal freedom, which is about autonomy and self-direction, and external freedom, which is about being able to act without external constraints.}, {Freedom as autonomy is a theory specifically about internal freedom.}, {A prisoner can have internal freedom by autonomously setting goals, even if they lack external freedom to act on them.}, {The intuition that a prisoner is unfree can be explained as a focus on external rather than internal freedom.}

bec9f4fc-52ba-416c-8f65-35b79aed67fd.summary: Rejecting the intuition that true autonomy requires external freedom
bec9f4fc-52ba-416c-8f65-35b79aed67fd.content: {It is mistaken to claim that a lack of ability to act on choices negates freedom as autonomy.}, {Autonomy is fundamentally about the self-direction aspect, not necessarily the immediate ability to act externally.}, {Even when external constraints exist, the capacity to set and plan future goals retains a form of freedom.}

d9ab2fb6-34a5-488a-9b5a-eec439510e0d.summary: Supplementing autonomy theory with opportunity to act
d9ab2fb6-34a5-488a-9b5a-eec439510e0d.content: {A supplementary assumption is that autonomy is best realized when paired with opportunities to act on choices, but it is not negated without them.}, {The autonomy component of freedom is maintained as long as self-governance and goal-setting are intact.}, {Opportunities to act are understood as an enhancement of freedom, but not its sole defining feature.}

5bac5718-adf7-4499-b1b1-f383640a0314.content: {Freedom requires the absence of coercion}, {Coercion involves external forces limiting one's choices}, {A person is free if they can make choices without external pressure}

6c2a3e23-167b-4598-9cc1-b419b8835583.summary: Freedom as Capacity for Autonomous Reflection
6c2a3e23-167b-4598-9cc1-b419b8835583.content: {Freedom involves the capacity for autonomous reflection}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can reflect on and endorse their own goals}

a74e2644-7294-4414-ab65-ba555ed07f8f.content: {Freedom can exist within certain constraints}, {Autonomy involves the ability to pursue one's own goals within limits}, {A person can be free even if not all options are available, as long as they can still pursue their essential goals}

5660a0d6-8a80-437e-a4c0-8d4ab7a9e33e.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own authentic choices}, {Authenticity involves actions aligning with one's true self}, {A person is free if their choices express their genuine desires and values}

ad03ef6e-ccb9-4c40-8da0-fcfa298f0b2e.content: {There is a key distinction between autonomy and the presence of coercion}, {Freedom as autonomy is a theory about self-direction rather than absence of coercion}, {A person can be autonomous if they act according to their own goals, even under coercive circumstances}, {The presence of coercion does not automatically negate autonomy if the individual can still act in line with their self-chosen goals}

a973fa66-1106-44eb-aa61-4295988eace3.summary: Rejecting the intuition that coercion always negates freedom
a973fa66-1106-44eb-aa61-4295988eace3.content: {It is mistaken to believe that coercion always negates freedom}, {Coercion may affect the options available, but autonomy is about the ability to pursue one's own chosen goals}, {Under some conditions, a person can still exercise autonomy by making a choice aligned with their own values, even if coerced}

43444525-7ee0-4b45-85a2-3d5bec62ab6d.summary: Acknowledging the complexity of autonomy under coercion
43444525-7ee0-4b45-85a2-3d5bec62ab6d.content: {Accept a supplementary assumption that autonomy is a matter of degree}, {Autonomy can be diminished by coercion but not necessarily eliminated}, {Freedom as autonomy acknowledges that individuals can still exhibit self-governance in choosing how to respond to coercive threats}

594429dd-b98a-47c6-8845-1af8ee2f742a.content: {Introduce the concept of layered autonomy where basic autonomy can persist under coercion}, {Basic autonomy concerns the fundamental ability to set goals despite external pressures}, {Even under coercion, a person may retain basic autonomy by selecting from available options in a way consistent with their deeper values}

13d9dffe-6c20-4c67-81e9-84750516925f.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {A person is free only if their choices are based on accurate and complete information}

494c501c-9510-4bce-8498-8a2fa7293ee0.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {Deliberation involves considering available information and possible outcomes}, {A person is free if they deliberate based on accurate information and pursue their own goals}

86eb8980-c551-4bf0-b75c-b1f801564a22.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own informed choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {An informed choice requires access to relevant and accurate information}

c6182fc1-04b1-4dd1-973d-02200c23d392.content: {Freedom consists in rational decision-making}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {Rational decision-making requires true and complete information}, {A person is free if they rationally set and pursue their own goals}

abfa08dc-94f0-40c8-9c2f-9381645b181d.content: {Freedom consists in making choices grounded in knowledge}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {Knowledge requires truth and belief based on justified information}, {A person is free if they act based on knowledge and pursue their own goals}

dc5854d6-9654-42c3-9441-182c22084ba5.summary: Distinction between external constraints and internal cognitive defects
dc5854d6-9654-42c3-9441-182c22084ba5.content: {There is a distinction between external impediments to action and internal cognitive defects within the agent's decision-making process}, {Freedom as autonomy is primarily concerned with the absence of external constraints on self-direction}, {Making a decision based on false information is an internal cognitive defect rather than an external constraint on autonomy}, {The intuition that freedom is compromised by misinformation can be explained by misunderstanding cognitive defects for violations of autonomy}

c3e15a30-98d0-489d-9e03-dabbef0ce5c6.summary: Rejecting the necessity of full information for autonomy
c3e15a30-98d0-489d-9e03-dabbef0ce5c6.content: {It is false that autonomy requires complete and accurate information}, {Autonomy is about the exercise of one’s capacity to choose goals and actions even when some information is lacking}, {A choice made based on false information does not necessarily undermine one's autonomy if the selection process itself aligns with one's self-directed goals}

b793eb31-38ee-4c6e-97f3-c082cddfdd27.summary: Supplementary assumption of sufficient rather than total information
b793eb31-38ee-4c6e-97f3-c082cddfdd27.content: {Autonomy requires sufficient, though not necessarily complete, information to make meaningful choices}, {Sufficient information allows individuals to generally understand the implications of their decisions}, {The key is whether the person believes they have adequate understanding, rather than possessing complete factual knowledge}

41359611-6171-4caa-9060-2df7798f246d.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {Achieving autonomy requires rational assessment and reflection on one's desires and goals}

8b7a527b-2c86-4b09-91ff-f8bb069c2298.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {True freedom requires the exercise of rational capacities to assess and modify internal impulses}

4002a1f8-a092-4cce-af2f-e7175eb345cb.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {Autonomy includes the integration of rational deliberations with emotional and psychological states}

fef396b9-cdb3-4f74-a520-18cce2b8e96d.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {Internal constraints such as irrational fears are compatible with autonomy if there exists an ability to critically evaluate them}

bb2ed52b-a17e-4327-a82c-400e19bf5581.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {Freedom includes the ability to exert self-control over irrational impulses through reflective processes}

9fd4cf4d-a5fb-47d7-825d-7c2dca7783c8.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {True autonomy requires making choices guided by rational deliberation over impulsive actions}

1637ecbd-55a4-4860-b3d8-f6e73d276ce2.content: {Freedom as Autonomy is concerned with rational self-direction rather than any form of self-direction}, {Irrational fears and compulsions are not instances of rational self-governance}, {A person acting on irrational fears is not exercising genuine autonomy}, {The intuition that irrational constraints limit freedom is correct within the framework of rational self-direction}

4f8cb8db-e3f1-4d3d-b5ff-4ddcac871e0c.summary: Clarifying autonomy as alignment with true self
4f8cb8db-e3f1-4d3d-b5ff-4ddcac871e0c.content: {There is a distinction between authentic autonomy and mere action based on internal states}, {Autonomy involves acting in accordance with one's true self, which is aligned with rational decision-making}, {Irrational fears or compulsions reflect misalignment with one's true self}, {Thus, actions based on irrational constraints do not reflect a genuine lack of autonomy when considering alignment with the true self}

c3427137-c221-4822-bb2c-53320a8599c9.summary: Supplementing with a reflective self-evaluation criterion
c3427137-c221-4822-bb2c-53320a8599c9.content: {Autonomy can involve an element of reflective self-evaluation in making choices}, {A reflective self-evaluation includes consideration of the rationality of one’s internal states}, {Acknowledging irrational fears or compulsions during reflective evaluation allows for genuine autonomous actions}, {With reflective self-evaluation, the presence of irrational constraints does not obstruct freedom as autonomy}

5f9759bd-a289-484d-a659-4e6debeb3cbe.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free only if they respect the autonomy of others}

4b1f73f2-4a2c-4b75-9ff1-865d5a87a18e.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if they pursue their own goals while maintaining the autonomy of others}

c1f9ce93-2b32-467f-84bd-5c2d1c39aecc.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free when their actions contribute to a community where all members can pursue their autonomous goals}

149bafab-a002-4919-a9b5-5b5fb96fdabb.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person is free if their autonomy choices support the autonomy of other individuals}

8eee3e40-44ad-482e-a8b0-898c19ab122b.summary: Cooperative Autonomy in a Moral Framework
8eee3e40-44ad-482e-a8b0-898c19ab122b.content: {Freedom consists in making one's own choices}, {Autonomy involves self-governance and self-direction}, {A person's freedom is not fully realized unless they engage in cooperative actions that respect and uphold others' autonomy}

27db46cc-1dfe-4d24-94ab-4c405636f416.summary: Distinguishing moral autonomy from personal autonomy
27db46cc-1dfe-4d24-94ab-4c405636f416.content: {Moral autonomy concerns adherence to moral principles, while personal autonomy is about individual goal-setting}, {A person can be personally autonomous without being morally autonomous}, {Freedom as autonomy primarily refers to personal autonomy, not moral autonomy}, {Violating others' autonomy does not necessarily undermine one's own personal autonomy}

d98c24c3-831f-4a6c-945a-6c3accfda40c.summary: Rejecting the intuition that violating others' autonomy compromises one's freedom
d98c24c3-831f-4a6c-945a-6c3accfda40c.content: {It is mistaken to equate violating others' autonomy with compromising one's own autonomy}, {The intuition conflates moral considerations with the condition of autonomy}, {Freedom as autonomy can remain intact even when moral principles are violated}, {A person can still be self-governing and self-directing while infringing on moral autonomy}

a9276fc7-75d9-4a16-ab5f-1e735853faba.content: {Moral pluralism suggests there are multiple, sometimes conflicting, principles at play}, {The pursuit of personal autonomy can coexist with tensions in moral autonomy}, {Respecting others' autonomy is one of many moral considerations, not an obligation that constrains freedom as autonomy}, {Freedom as self-direction does not preclude moral conflicts}

6477c904-236a-4f84-83a3-d58597658bbb.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {Freedom includes the absence of manipulative influences over an individual's decision-making process}

0b69fa89-9d52-4611-a491-4aaaa76527de.content: {Freedom is the ability to make one's own choices}, {A person is free if they can form and pursue their own goals}, {Liberty involves not being coerced or manipulated by others}, {Individual autonomy includes freedom from both domination and manipulation}

51f72255-7b75-46c9-93f7-83450d16cea0.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Freedom requires the ability to make decisions based on accurate and rational information}, {Liberty involves protecting individuals from manipulative and misleading information}

15e0f544-0fa4-42ab-b6a4-8eb636aa13b6.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Freedom involves having the capabilities necessary to make genuine choices}, {Liberty requires the empowerment of individuals to resist manipulation}

f3e59bd7-41e8-4746-9c99-dac88eaf8a67.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves making decisions based on informed and voluntary consent}, {Freedom is compromised by actions that undermine informed decision-making capabilities}

2e45b4fb-7391-4597-bdbc-482b475e91b6.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {Freedom includes protection against subtle subversion of autonomy through misleading influences}

36063996-d133-4fb6-b15b-14a4a77e62b3.content: {There is a distinction between overt domination and subtle manipulation}, {Freedom as non-domination primarily concerns the absence of overt domination, not all forms of influence}, {Manipulative influences that do not involve direct control fall outside the scope of non-domination}, {The intuition that freedom is compromised by manipulation can be explained by conflating this with overt domination}

e0867e10-7f83-4a65-85ea-e6a18a3a8589.summary: Rejecting the intuition that manipulation undermines freedom
e0867e10-7f83-4a65-85ea-e6a18a3a8589.content: {It is false that freedom is compromised merely by being subject to manipulative influences}, {Freedom as non-domination does not entail absolute insulation from all forms of influence}, {The integrity of freedom is maintained as long as there is no arbitrary power exerted over the individual}, {The perception of compromised freedom is mistaken unless it involves actual domination}

88c72b64-55c0-4784-983e-3388722e2b1a.summary: Including manipulation under the assumption of arbitrary power
88c72b64-55c0-4784-983e-3388722e2b1a.content: {Supplementary assumption that manipulation can constitute arbitrary power}, {Manipulative influences can represent arbitrary power if they systematically undermine autonomy}, {Freedom as non-domination can include protection from significant manipulative tactics}, {The theory can accommodate manipulative scenarios by viewing them as potential sources of arbitrary power}

d380e21b-7856-4f29-8ddf-85b785ab9914.content: The system was unable to generate a synthesis from this thesis-antithesis pair.

9b62da06-3188-443e-9941-417fcb9aaefe.content: {Freedom is the absence of structural conditions leading to domination}, {A person is free if social and institutional structures do not inherently favor domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from indirectly being under someone else's control through institutional bias}

0ab0b477-af7b-4b20-8dc3-1c3470c190e3.content: {Freedom is the presence of capacities necessary to challenge potential domination}, {A person is free if they possess the means and resources to counteract power imbalances}, {Liberty involves empowerment to negotiate power relations on more equal terms}

42247f27-4845-4d8d-ba17-43aa148190ae.summary: Freedom as the Capability to Resist
42247f27-4845-4d8d-ba17-43aa148190ae.content: {Freedom includes the capability to resist domination effectively}, {A person is free if they can resist or reform potentially dominating structures}, {Liberty involves practical means to reform or resist dominating forces}

1dec1493-501a-4563-9af6-88aedc3f133f.content: {Freedom is the absence of dependence upon potentially dominating powers}, {A person is free if they do not rely on others who possess significantly more power}, {Liberty involves economic and social independence reducing vulnerability to domination}

862665d4-bf54-4403-86ea-5b544ef1ac71.summary: Distinguishing between power imbalance and domination
862665d4-bf54-4403-86ea-5b544ef1ac71.content: {There is a distinction between power imbalances and actual instances of domination}, {Freedom as non-domination is a theory about domination rather than mere power imbalances}, {A power imbalance does not entail that the less powerful are actually dominated if there is no arbitrary interference}, {The intuition that the less powerful are unfree can be explained by conflating powerlessness with domination}

3434c632-d0e1-4a33-a9a4-50aa66c6fffa.summary: Rejecting the necessity of practical ability to challenge
3434c632-d0e1-4a33-a9a4-50aa66c6fffa.content: {It is false that freedom requires the practical ability to challenge power structures}, {Freedom as non-domination entails protection from arbitrary interference, not empowerment to resist all power imbalances}, {The absence of recourse does not necessarily imply domination if arbitrary power is not exercised}

5b3426e9-67b9-40d0-9d4e-5eafa42a8bfa.content: {Freedom as non-domination may presuppose the existence of institutional safeguards against arbitrary power}, {A system of laws and checks can prevent arbitrary interference even in contexts of power imbalance}, {The practical ability to challenge power may not be required if sufficient institutional protections ensure non-domination}

feea3258-d2f4-4a82-873b-a46c8dba3979.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {Collective decisions enhance freedom if they are made through a democratic process where all individuals can participate equally}

26646faf-cfdb-421c-a49f-b082d3d9bfa8.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {Any constraint on freedom imposed by collective decisions must be the result of fair procedures in which all affected individuals have a say}

6199011c-13e6-41f8-8af2-fac806a4012c.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {Individuals maintain freedom when constraints arise from collectively agreed-upon norms or principles}

658884ac-bd7f-4c30-a5dc-f61201f0f087.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {Freedom takes into account the relational context, recognizing that collective constraints can coexist with individual freedom when mutual recognition and respect guide interactions}

f3c0e914-de09-4e31-a97e-d71ac19c7b30.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {Freedom involves considering long-term patterns of interaction where temporary collective constraints are balanced by opportunities for changing roles and influencing decisions over time}

ffdec46a-7086-44e7-ae1b-3c9e8f9f6262.summary: Distinguishing between individual and collective freedom
ffdec46a-7086-44e7-ae1b-3c9e8f9f6262.content: {There is a distinction between individual freedom and collective freedom}, {Freedom as non-domination concerns individual freedom from arbitrary power}, {Constraints arising from democratic decision-making do not constitute domination if they are non-arbitrary and reflect the collective will}, {The freedom of individuals in the minority is not diminished under non-domination if democratic processes do not involve arbitrary control}

af9e9bdd-06b6-40d1-8c3a-a34e51b3ba48.summary: Recalibrating the role of democratic decision-making
af9e9bdd-06b6-40d1-8c3a-a34e51b3ba48.content: {Democratic decision-making is not an instance of domination if the process reflects fair participation and accountability}, {Feeling constrained by collective decisions does not equate to being dominated in the non-domination sense}, {The inability to pursue personal preferences against the majority's will does not amount to a lack of freedom if decisions are made without arbitrary power}

843358aa-fa55-476f-99be-1f09d4d3149e.summary: Incorporating procedural fairness as a supplementary assumption
843358aa-fa55-476f-99be-1f09d4d3149e.content: {Procedural fairness ensures that collective decisions are not arbitrary}, {Freedom as non-domination involves protection from arbitrary governance, which is addressed by procedural fairness}, {A minority's freedom is not compromised if collective decisions are made through fair and transparent processes}

842941a5-0273-420b-b9e9-85289a26bfd6.summary: Rejecting the intuition that collective constraints equate to diminished freedom
842941a5-0273-420b-b9e9-85289a26bfd6.content: {The claim that collective constraints diminish freedom due to inability to pursue personal preferences is mistaken}, {Differences in preference after collective decisions do not imply domination if derived from fair processes}, {Collective decision-making's fairness retains individuals' non-domination even if they are part of the minority}

c86cb03a-58fa-4ce9-94a8-2043c683c747.content: {Freedom is the mutual recognition of individuals as autonomous beings}, {A person is free if they acknowledge and respect the autonomy of others}, {Liberty involves the protection of autonomy through mutual recognition among individuals}

8b4e8ec4-5177-4c1c-8727-b75951278b9b.content: {Freedom is ensured by institutional structures that prevent domination}, {A person is free if institutions guarantee protection from domination}, {Liberty involves having institutional protections that minimize the need for constant individual vigilance}

3b38df85-d7b3-40b8-a7d1-4aa7c06a38c0.content: {Freedom is guaranteed by a robust legal system that prevents domination}, {A person is free if laws ensure they are protected from domination}, {Liberty involves legal frameworks that provide protection against the infringement of autonomy}

2fc9c179-34e1-4c24-a170-13abb774d57e.content: {Freedom involves empowerment to pursue one's aspirations without domination}, {A person is free if they are positively empowered to act freely while being protected from domination}, {Liberty includes developing personal and social conditions where positive empowerment negates domination}

76989b59-fb0f-442c-a3bb-bee2918d8e3e.content: {Freedom is supported by communal networks that prevent domination}, {A person is free if their community provides support against potential domination}, {Liberty involves building supportive networks that buffer individuals from both external and internal domination}

850ab3a7-a29f-4ec7-9acf-6cf6c33e9630.summary: Distinguishing vigilant awareness from actual constraint
850ab3a7-a29f-4ec7-9acf-6cf6c33e9630.content: {There is a distinction between vigilant awareness and actual imposition of constraints on freedom}, {Vigilant awareness in and of itself does not constitute a constraint on freedom}, {Freedom as non-domination is a theory about absence of arbitrary control, not about one's internal sentiment of vigilance}, {The need to monitor for potential domination does not infringe on freedom if actual domination is absent}, {The intuition that constant vigilance compromises freedom can be explained by confusing vigilance with being unfree}

bdfee6a2-c883-4694-90ab-8067b5922b1f.summary: Rejecting fear as equivalent to unfreedom
bdfee6a2-c883-4694-90ab-8067b5922b1f.content: {It is false that fear of potential forces of domination itself constitutes a lack of freedom}, {Genuine freedom is about the absence of arbitrary interference rather than the presence or absence of fear}, {A person can be fully free even when they remain vigilant against potential threats}, {The perception of reduced freedom due to vigilance is a mistaken equating of psychological states with factual constraints}

8868d1e0-46f9-40c1-a134-9a0d2df3abeb.summary: Supplementing with commitment to democratic structures
8868d1e0-46f9-40c1-a134-9a0d2df3abeb.content: {Strong democratic structures provide mechanisms that negate arbitrary power, reducing the need for perpetual vigilance}, {The concept of freedom as non-domination incorporates a societal commitment to uphold democratic processes}, {With robust democratic safeguards, individuals are free from undue imposition without perpetual self-imposed constraint}, {The role of institutional frameworks is to ensure freedom without necessitating constant personal monitoring}

f87e3ac6-8fa0-423b-81b1-4a4632063f00.content: {Freedom is having the power to shape one's life within a social context}, {A person is free if they have access to education, resources, and opportunities}, {Liberty necessitates conditions that enable individuals to actively participate in decision-making}

f4c768aa-4d7d-4218-90e8-daac12a50a14.content: {Freedom is the ability to determine one's own fate}, {A person is free if they can make life choices without being subject to external pressures}, {Liberty means being able to act according to personal values and aspirations}

2b1f7008-de08-4b24-bbf4-f90cc4a32d97.content: {There is a distinction between freedom as non-domination and personal autonomy.}, {Freedom as non-domination is primarily concerned with the absence of arbitrary external power.}, {Personal autonomy involves the capacity to pursue one's desires and life plans.}, {A person can be free from domination while still lacking personal autonomy due to internal constraints.}, {The theory of freedom as non-domination does not claim to address all aspects of personal autonomy.}

0bb34aac-698a-44b5-b91a-9f8957cc1074.summary: Rejecting the necessity of autonomy for freedom
0bb34aac-698a-44b5-b91a-9f8957cc1074.content: {It is false that true freedom must include the capacity for personal autonomy.}, {The central focus of freedom as non-domination is the absence of arbitrary interference, not the presence of personal autonomy.}, {A person can still be considered free if they are not subjected to domination, even if personal constraints limit their autonomy.}, {The theory of freedom as non-domination encompasses protection against domination but does not address all forms of personal limitation.}

4a36915d-a6b8-41a3-8443-3dcb3bbe3304.summary: Supplementary assumption of resources for autonomy
4a36915d-a6b8-41a3-8443-3dcb3bbe3304.content: {An implicit supplementary assumption of adequate resources is necessary for full autonomy.}, {Freedom as non-domination implicitly presumes a baseline level of resources that allows individuals to pursue their desires.}, {With adequate resources, individuals have greater capacity for autonomy and life planning.}, {The absence of domination provides a foundation on which personal autonomy can be built when resources are available.}

80ab7981-6cd5-48a8-aced-a1c2ad4b291d.summary: Freedom as Non-Domination Revised with Consent
80ab7981-6cd5-48a8-aced-a1c2ad4b291d.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {A person is not free if their acceptance of influence stems from implicit pressures that they cannot readily reject}

45163359-b828-46c4-952d-794075e688af.summary: Freedom as Non-Domination Emphasizing Autonomous Capacity
45163359-b828-46c4-952d-794075e688af.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {Authentic freedom requires the capacity to reject influence even in long-standing relationships}

c1830b73-17fe-4f65-83a9-1b6172c31114.summary: Freedom as Non-Domination with Explicit Consent Criteria
c1830b73-17fe-4f65-83a9-1b6172c31114.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {A person remains free only if their significant acceptance of influence is accompanied by explicit consent}

a38f54b6-0f5e-4e6f-856c-f5394d01e7e6.summary: Freedom as Non-Domination with Social Context Awareness
a38f54b6-0f5e-4e6f-856c-f5394d01e7e6.content: {Freedom is the absence of arbitrary power over the individual}, {A person is free if they are not subject to domination by others}, {Liberty involves protection from being under someone else's control without recourse}, {A person's freedom is assessed by considering the broader social context that may impose constraints on their decisions}

7675bcca-78f0-4b6b-b5d0-6c27b4eea791.summary: Distinguishing between explicit and tacit consent
7675bcca-78f0-4b6b-b5d0-6c27b4eea791.content: {There is a distinction between explicit and tacit consent.}, {Freedom as non-domination primarily concerns the presence or absence of explicit domination.}, {Tacit consent does not necessarily equate to domination as it might not involve arbitrary power.}, {Relationships of tacit influence do not inherently undermine freedom as non-domination if they do not involve the use of arbitrary power.}

a6c2d1a8-7feb-4ce3-aad4-7a699ed2cfa3.summary: Rejection of tacit consent undermining autonomy
a6c2d1a8-7feb-4ce3-aad4-7a699ed2cfa3.content: {The notion that tacit consent inherently limits autonomy is false.}, {A person can maintain autonomous choice within long-standing social relationships if these do not involve arbitrary power.}, {Dependence does not equate to domination if it includes the capacity for recourse and renegotiation.}

3ae96937-9343-4bca-a202-84be7fb4208b.summary: Supplementation with a norm of contestability
3ae96937-9343-4bca-a202-84be7fb4208b.content: {Introduce a norm of contestability as part of freedom as non-domination.}, {Freedom includes the ability to contest and renegotiate the terms of influence and direction.}, {Even within tacitly consented relationships, if power is contestable, it need not be arbitrary.}, {The ability to contest ensures social and psychological constraints can be renegotiated, preserving freedom as non-domination.}

095f9432-4bae-4e8b-8d50-c1d29f4cb169.content: {Freedom is the capacity to make choices based on one's own reasoning}, {A person is free if they can act according to their own preferences and desires}, {Liberty involves the ability to act independently of external constraints and internal compulsions}

737f4d97-151f-4606-8a72-d50af15cab6b.content: {Freedom is the ability to act through reason and reflection}, {A person is free if they can evaluate options and select actions based on rational deliberation}, {Liberty involves the capacity to pursue long-term goals through reasoned decision-making}

85e96038-0214-44ce-aca9-6dfe088d1ee0.content: {Freedom is the power to govern oneself without external imposition}, {A person is free if they can make choices that reflect their authentic self}, {Liberty involves the capability to shape one's own life path and identity}

98546953-309f-4969-bc3f-0c743646b1b5.content: {Freedom is characterized by the absence of external constraints on action}, {A person is free if there are no external obstacles to their desires}, {Liberty involves having options without interference from others}

8b475e25-b3e7-40b2-a841-4cdaa92e9323.content: {Freedom is the enhancement of one's capabilities to achieve personal goals}, {A person is free if they have the resources and capabilities to pursue their aspirations}, {Liberty involves the growth of personal and social circumstances that allow fulfilling one's potential}

c16c7628-70df-4788-bed3-b6ff10a599e6.content: {Freedom is the ability to innovate and create within one's life choices}, {A person is free if they can explore and realize creative potentials}, {Liberty involves embracing novelty and transformation in one's actions}

8c150de7-b599-47cf-a675-8bbeb6cf2def.summary: Freedom includes acting contrary to moral understanding
8c150de7-b599-47cf-a675-8bbeb6cf2def.content: {Distinguishing between freedom as moral capacity and freedom as autonomy of choice}, {Freedom as moral capacity focuses on the alignment of actions with moral principles over simple autonomy.}, {It is possible to retain freedom even when acting contrary to one's moral understanding through autonomous deliberation.}

bc3810d0-d7d6-40f1-ac45-fbd39618c8c6.summary: Freedom requires ability to overcome internal weaknesses and external pressures
bc3810d0-d7d6-40f1-ac45-fbd39618c8c6.content: {Freedom involves not only moral understanding but also the capacity to act on it despite internal weaknesses and external pressures}, {A person is free if they possess the strength to resist external pressures and internal weaknesses when aligning actions with moral understanding}, {Freedom includes the ability to choose actions aligned or contrary to one's moral understanding by overcoming imposed limitations.}

cfdb49e1-94f9-43f4-b011-a0ce2702e431.summary: Including capacity for moral reflection in the concept of freedom
cfdb49e1-94f9-43f4-b011-a0ce2702e431.content: {Freedom involves the capacity for moral reflection and revision of one's moral understanding}, {It is incomplete to consider freedom solely as moral alignment without the capacity for moral reassessment}, {Freedom includes choosing to reassess and potentially act against current moral understanding, reflecting deeper autonomy.}

2c0e5b7c-eaf1-4cb0-81f7-dff0f16eb53e.content: {Freedom is the ability to act according to one's own independent judgment}, {A person is free if they can critically evaluate and choose their moral principles}, {Liberty involves the capacity to question and revise one's moral beliefs}

5a8a4468-5ae6-4994-8642-81063bd0fb56.content: {Freedom is the ability to make decisions based on rational reflection}, {A person is free if they can govern themselves through reason rather than external influence}, {Liberty involves the ability to self-govern in the pursuit of personal values}

ee8d750d-9a8b-4ffa-982a-08298675d92f.content: {Freedom is the exercise of rational deliberation in decision-making}, {A person is free if they can will actions based on rational choice}, {Liberty involves the capability to act on considered rational grounds}

6d97e749-16fc-4e52-94e5-a3d19cc48daa.content: {Freedom is the capacity to decide with full understanding of options}, {A person is free if they can consent to actions based on informed knowledge}, {Liberty involves making choices with an awareness of their implications}

818a08d7-893a-4adc-895a-a180a89ec3a6.content: {Freedom is the capability to undertake moral responsibility}, {A person is free if they willingly accept responsibility for their moral actions}, {Liberty involves understanding and accepting the consequences of moral choices}

a6ec4b38-8cac-415e-a3a0-3efbe7c9a44a.content: {There is a distinction between acting independently and acting due to external conditioning}, {Freedom as moral capacity requires independent judgment, not mere conformity}, {Acting in alignment with moral principles through indoctrination does not fulfill the criteria for genuine liberty in the sense of moral capacity}

55c12bf0-d309-4061-ad97-0698cef250a3.summary: Rejecting the need for revising principles
55c12bf0-d309-4061-ad97-0698cef250a3.content: {It is not necessary for genuine liberty to require constant questioning and revising of one's moral principles}, {Freedom as moral capacity can be consistent with stable adherence to well-understood moral beliefs}, {Liberty involves acting according to moral understanding, which can be achieved without perpetual doubt or revision}

067bcfac-d722-44a3-b9fe-b630bc3f18f1.summary: Supplementing with the authenticity of moral understanding
067bcfac-d722-44a3-b9fe-b630bc3f18f1.content: {Liberty requires an authentic understanding and commitment to moral principles}, {An authentic comprehension of moral truths excludes blind adherence due to indoctrination}, {Genuine freedom involves sincere engagement with moral truths, not just a facade of compliance}

1565dd7b-c6ee-444b-91eb-c7797cdf2fbf.content: {Freedom is the ability to act according to one's own preferences}, {A person is free if they can make choices independently of external coercion}, {Liberty involves the autonomy to determine personal actions}

e71bda46-50d0-49b6-916d-a29a517789fa.content: {Freedom is the ability to act in accordance with one's reflective endorsements}, {A person is free if their actions align with values they reflectively endorse}, {Liberty involves the capacity to reflect on and choose one's values}

bf53d58b-7f8b-4d93-8c8a-249e9ccbf756.content: {Freedom is the capacity to act effectively to achieve one's ends}, {A person is free if they can successfully pursue their goals}, {Liberty involves the capability to bring about desired outcomes}

78ea7590-c5f0-49a8-b25e-90ce31dfcb65.content: {Freedom as moral capacity does not require perfect moral discernment.}, {A person can still be free as long as they can act according to whatever level of moral understanding they possess.}, {The objection conflates complete moral discernment with the capacity to follow one's moral insights, however limited.}

3a628e81-1d1e-4c31-8b51-e36330ebf1ed.summary: Rejecting necessity of moral discernment for freedom
3a628e81-1d1e-4c31-8b51-e36330ebf1ed.content: {It is false that freedom requires the capacity to fully discern moral truths.}, {Freedom involves acting according to one’s understanding of morality, regardless of its completeness.}, {The core of freedom is acting in coherence with one's beliefs, not possessing infallible moral knowledge.}

3adbd9e8-f2ca-413d-94ac-3fb20df41251.summary: Supplementing with a broader concept of individualized moral insight
3adbd9e8-f2ca-413d-94ac-3fb20df41251.content: {Freedom as moral capacity can include various levels of moral insight.}, {Individuals possess viable freedom when capable of acting according to their subjective moral framework.}, {This framework allows for the possibility that freedom encompasses personal moral interpretations, irrespective of their objectivity.}

ca465700-2ff3-4bc2-bc33-7c1c7cd43b89.content: {Freedom is the ability to align actions with autonomously chosen moral principles}, {A person is free if they can act according to their autonomously developed moral understanding}, {Liberty involves the capacity to discern and enact autonomously chosen values}

604d0221-3f07-4cc3-a58e-4f1caaba29a0.content: {Freedom involves actions that are reflectively endorsed by the individual}, {A person is free if they can critically reflect on their moral principles and choose to act in accordance with them}, {Liberty requires the capacity for reflective self-evaluation and endorsement of one's moral principles}

e3b213e5-737e-4191-b991-cf029ed27230.content: {Freedom requires non-coerced alignment with moral principles}, {A person is free if they can align their actions with moral understanding independently of external coercion}, {Liberty is the capacity to act according to one's moral understanding without external coercive influences}

ffd55206-2a68-4772-8b7c-eaf7c2d602f6.content: {Freedom entails acting according to moral principles that are authentically one's own}, {A person is free if they can engage with moral principles that stem from their genuine self}, {Liberty involves the capacity for authentic self-expression in moral decision-making}

4af966a4-68bf-4191-a523-a5324556406f.content: {Freedom involves the capacity to self-determine one's alignment with moral principles}, {A person is free if they self-determine their moral understanding and act upon it}, {Liberty requires the ability to determine one's actions based on self-chosen moral values}

3f9ee7d8-9ad2-4d6b-8d89-2d3dd2633554.summary: Distinguishing internal and external moral alignment
3f9ee7d8-9ad2-4d6b-8d89-2d3dd2633554.content: {There is a distinction between internal moral alignment and external moral alignment}, {Freedom as moral capacity focuses on internal moral alignment rather than external coercion}, {Adherence to moral understanding under coercion is not genuine freedom in the relevant sense of internal moral alignment}, {The challenge arises from a confusion between freedom as internal moral alignment and externally imposed actions}

8e0186c9-cd6a-4d80-a562-cb858ae82eb9.summary: Rejecting external influence as negating freedom
8e0186c9-cd6a-4d80-a562-cb858ae82eb9.content: {It is false that aligning actions with morality under external influence negates freedom}, {Freedom as moral capacity emphasizes the ability to choose one's moral principles independently of external force}, {The presence of coercion does not necessarily undermine one's fundamental moral capacity as long as the choice aligns with internal values}

50a93e8e-1942-4efd-a39e-07897f54463f.summary: Balancing moral capacity with voluntary action
50a93e8e-1942-4efd-a39e-07897f54463f.content: {Freedom as moral capacity necessitates a supplementary component of voluntary action}, {The ability to discern and independently enact what is right requires supplementing moral understanding with voluntary choice}, {Freedom involves both internal moral capacity and the absence of coercion, allowing for genuine voluntary actions}

22fc3ccb-9fa3-448c-a935-395e2d8d7c3e.content: {Freedom is the ability to make autonomous choices}, {A person is free if they can act independently of external constraints}, {Liberty involves having the capacity to choose without being subject to undue influence}

8c54cefc-e32e-4c2f-89e8-cd1da093fcb3.content: {Freedom is the ability to make personal choices}, {A person is free if they can select actions based on personal preferences}, {Liberty involves the capacity to choose for oneself, even if the choices are not aligned with moral principles}

082a40a9-6e14-4cba-a00e-fd3e0a806c78.content: {Freedom is the absence of coercion}, {A person is free if they are not subject to force or threats}, {Liberty involves the capacity to act without being compelled by external forces}

d6092237-bfc9-4bec-99b2-9cf9b342cebd.content: {Freedom is the capacity for self-determination}, {A person is free if they can determine their own path in life}, {Liberty involves the ability to make choices that define one's own identity}

2d4dea66-9f87-4914-8eb0-46229781def0.content: {Freedom is having opportunities available}, {A person is free if they have access to a range of options}, {Liberty involves the capacity to pursue different paths in life based on available opportunities}

9e9e79fb-c847-461b-833e-20162042a23b.content: {Freedom is the state of non-domination}, {A person is free if they are not subject to arbitrary control by others}, {Liberty involves being in a position where one is not vulnerable to the will of others}

afec68e1-55ce-4582-9d65-7b175af92049.content: {Freedom is the lack of interference by others}, {A person is free if they can act without others intervening}, {Liberty involves having the space to act without external obstruction}

c1df9311-eee3-4524-b263-87efeeaf226e.content: {Freedom is the ability to act authentically}, {A person is free if they can live in accordance with their true self}, {Liberty involves the capacity to realize one's own identity and desires}

14299517-45c7-408d-bf9c-9c00c56f7cf4.summary: Distinguishing between moral and external constraints
14299517-45c7-408d-bf9c-9c00c56f7cf4.content: {There is a distinction between moral capacity and external constraints such as laws or societal norms}, {Freedom as moral capacity is concerned with the internal ability to act morally, not with external limitations}, {A person possessing moral understanding remains free in the relevant sense even if constrained by external factors}, {The ability to act immorally does not provide a more accurate understanding of freedom in the moral capacity sense}

dbe8aa44-37bd-426f-b5ba-0a7c58218c04.summary: Rejecting that moral capacity is unnecessary for freedom
dbe8aa44-37bd-426f-b5ba-0a7c58218c04.content: {It is mistaken to claim that freedom must exclude moral considerations to accommodate personal autonomy}, {The presence of personal autonomy does not negate the need for moral capacity as a facet of freedom}, {Moral capacity enriches freedom by informing choices consistent with ethical principles}, {Examples of freedom exercised without moral understanding do not demonstrate the irrelevance of moral capacity}

aaff8012-6448-441a-85b3-96b021835a17.summary: Supplementary assumption of a dual capacity model
aaff8012-6448-441a-85b3-96b021835a17.content: {Freedom can involve more than one type of capacity, including moral and autonomous capacity}, {Moral capacity can coexist with autonomous choice as complementary aspects of freedom}, {A dual capacity model explains that freedom is enhanced when both moral and autonomous capacities are present}, {This model acknowledges that individuals may act freely without one capacity by relying on the other}

fb527e3b-58e7-45ca-8b4e-a9e645b30208.content: {Freedom is the ability to make autonomous choices}, {A person is free if they can follow their own desires and preferences}, {Liberty involves being free from external constraints on decision-making}

82286763-2411-4854-a746-3e3ce388c08d.content: {Freedom is the capacity to make decisions based on rational deliberation}, {A person is free if they can act according to reason over impulses}, {Liberty involves the ability to evaluate reasons and choose accordingly}

e545927d-9991-4d67-9922-01593f31dc66.content: {Freedom is the power to determine one's own actions}, {A person is free if they can set and pursue their own goals}, {Liberty involves control over one's own life choices}

955a9f28-c41a-4038-9210-b223db55a9c4.content: {Freedom is the absence of coercion by others}, {A person is free if they are not subject to the force or will of another}, {Liberty involves living without being controlled by others}

051b25aa-078b-480c-8142-933ceabb4ecc.content: {Freedom is involvement in collective decision-making}, {A person is free if they can participate in the democratic process}, {Liberty involves active engagement in shaping the political and social environment}

67da5c0e-62a9-4e11-8b1b-a1cfa4dd2430.content: {Freedom is the alignment of individual actions with societal norms}, {A person is free if their behaviors are accepted within their society}, {Liberty involves freedom to act within the boundaries of social conventions}

4b7e2df6-04a6-4f75-a6b6-98b1633f55da.content: {Freedom is the ability to act effectively within existing frameworks}, {A person is free if they can coordinate their actions with others to achieve goals}, {Liberty involves the efficient aligning of individual actions with practical structures}

4166e72e-010b-4021-b244-0f094c7b4cd5.content: {Freedom is the pursuit of self-improvement}, {A person is free if they can develop their personal potential}, {Liberty involves the capacity to grow and evolve as an individual}

4a4bfbf4-ecbc-406c-9dd8-96fcbb878e21.summary: Distinguishing social freedom from moral capacity
4a4bfbf4-ecbc-406c-9dd8-96fcbb878e21.content: {There is a distinction between moral freedom and social or legal freedom}, {Freedom as moral capacity is specifically about moral freedom rather than social or legal freedom}, {A person who acts in accordance with societal norms without moral understanding might be socially free but not morally free}, {Moral freedom involves the ability to discern and act upon moral principles, not just conform to social standards}

e120f9b4-f1df-4dee-91f4-84fb11a6c4da.summary: Rejecting moral ignorance as a barrier to freedom
e120f9b4-f1df-4dee-91f4-84fb11a6c4da.content: {It is false that individuals lacking moral understanding are never free}, {Freedom involves potential for moral growth and understanding over time}, {A person can be initially ignorant but still possess the capacity to develop moral understanding, which is an aspect of freedom}

d4b46036-19a3-41c9-a4c5-ad9c59669ab4.summary: Supplementary role of societal norms in moral capacity
d4b46036-19a3-41c9-a4c5-ad9c59669ab4.content: {Societal norms can provide a framework for developing moral understanding}, {While freedom as moral capacity emphasizes individual moral comprehension, societal influence can guide the development of such comprehension}, {The presence of social norms does not entail full freedom but supports the growth towards it}

13296e23-9bcf-4124-bf9b-6d51eda0e6f5.content: {Freedom is the ability to make choices independently of external influences}, {A person is free if they can act according to their own desires and motivations}, {Liberty involves the capacity to make personal decisions without coercion}

e5787bc6-ed07-4a19-a438-8494e93bcb89.content: {Freedom is the ability to govern oneself through reason}, {A person is free if they can act in accordance with rational deliberation}, {Liberty involves the capacity to act based on reasoned choice rather than unexamined impulse}

d590f57a-896e-4001-9ba9-9710e680c4af.content: {Freedom is the capacity to act in accordance with one's will}, {A person is free if they can make choices according to their own volition}, {Liberty involves the ability to act without being constrained by external forces}

5055436d-3e0b-4e90-8bdf-815399bd1791.content: {There is a distinction between moral freedom and other types of freedom, such as personal or external freedom}, {Freedom as moral capacity specifically concerns the alignment of actions with moral principles}, {The intuition that one can be free while acting on irrational whims is a different conception of personal freedom}, {The experience of freedom when acting against moral principles can be explained by appealing to forms of freedom not covered by moral capacity}

9c74be1c-a806-4103-9138-5a4f788a6317.summary: Rejecting the intuition of freedom without moral alignment
9c74be1c-a806-4103-9138-5a4f788a6317.content: {The intuition that one can act freely without aligning with moral principles is mistaken}, {Freedom as moral capacity posits that true freedom involves acting in accordance with one's moral understanding}, {The feeling of freedom when acting irrationally or against moral beliefs is an illusion rather than genuine liberty}

6ba0ce99-93f7-4b43-b3dd-76a3c7fe2ad5.summary: Supplementary assumption of multiple dimensions of freedom
6ba0ce99-93f7-4b43-b3dd-76a3c7fe2ad5.content: {Freedom can have multiple dimensions, such as moral, personal, and social freedom}, {Freedom as moral capacity addresses only the moral dimension of freedom}, {Incorporating additional dimensions of freedom provides a comprehensive understanding of how actions might be considered free in various contexts}

25145e27-58a3-4087-9487-979204bdb82b.content: {Freedom involves the autonomous commitment to moral principles}, {A person is free if they voluntarily choose to act according to their moral understanding}, {Liberty includes the capacity to pursue personal values in alignment with morality}

6eabaf47-3458-4f39-ba9d-8af2d8c104aa.content: {Freedom is the ability to reflectively endorse one's actions}, {A person is free if their actions are guided by values they reflectively endorse}, {Liberty involves critical reflection on and endorsement of moral principles}

c544eb33-03c4-43d3-98d8-e58e4790571d.content: {Freedom involves integration of personal values and moral principles}, {A person is free if they harmonize their personal values with moral understanding}, {Liberty requires integrating moral insights into one's value system}

2ab518dd-6f0e-4b26-ab5c-4bdfee4fad7b.content: {Freedom is the volitional enactment of moral principles}, {A person is free if they willingly act according to their moral code}, {Liberty involves choosing to endorse and enact what is morally right}

a7ab272a-8c35-4be0-aa33-08fa092636c8.content: {Freedom involves a multiplicity of moral commitments}, {A person is free if they navigate different moral principles autonomously}, {Liberty requires the freedom to select and prioritize among diverse moral values}

fab65f63-fa39-4630-a2d9-877f397c164a.summary: Distinguishing between coerced and voluntary moral alignment
fab65f63-fa39-4630-a2d9-877f397c164a.content: {There is a distinction between coerced alignment with moral principles and voluntary alignment with them}, {Freedom as moral capacity is a theory about voluntary moral alignment rather than coerced moral behavior}, {A person coerced into aligning with moral principles is not exercising the relevant moral capacity, as their actions do not reflect personal moral endorsement}, {The intuition that coerced moral behavior lacks liberty can be explained by the absence of voluntary moral alignment}

044298c1-e004-4800-bfee-76e34b35a260.summary: Rejecting the need for personal endorsement in moral capacity
044298c1-e004-4800-bfee-76e34b35a260.content: {It is false that freedom as moral capacity requires personal endorsement of moral principles}, {Moral capacity can be exercised even if actions are not personally endorsed, as long as they align with moral understanding}, {The absence of personal commitment does not imply a lack of liberty if moral principles are still being followed}

dab0ad43-c8fb-4d80-bd5f-036230d1b137.summary: Arguing that moral understanding implies internalization of values
dab0ad43-c8fb-4d80-bd5f-036230d1b137.content: {Freedom as the capacity to align actions with moral principles implies internalization of those values}, {If a person understands moral principles, they have, to some degree, internalized those values}, {The appearance of lacking liberty under coercion can be addressed by understanding that moral comprehension entails a baseline of value acceptance}

95f9e014-cdc0-403e-bd49-e13efbfb65c7.summary: Supplementing with the assumption that liberty can be partial
95f9e014-cdc0-403e-bd49-e13efbfb65c7.content: {Liberty might be understood as occurring on a spectrum, where partial freedom is possible}, {A coerced alignment with moral principles reflects partial rather than full liberty}, {The objection loses force when acknowledging that degrees of liberty exist, allowing for some freedom even under coercion}

530bc88b-43d4-4dcd-bbce-273a20165bc4.content: {Freedom is the expression of rational self-control}, {A person is free if they can act based on reason}, {Liberty involves the ability to evaluate decisions through rational reflection}

5e0d0b44-6c29-433f-8205-bb78d5ee685d.content: {Freedom is the capacity for personal autonomy}, {A person is free if they can make choices according to their own desires}, {Liberty involves the power to pursue individual goals without external constraints}

9f21586b-2f58-4029-83b9-97d3671129e4.content: {Freedom is characterized by the absence of coercion}, {A person is free if no external force compels their actions}, {Liberty involves living without undue external pressure or interference}

48aa8c93-6b67-4328-9d9d-6267df1a938f.content: {Freedom is the ability to make volitional choices}, {A person is free if they can act based on their own volition}, {Liberty involves exercising individual willpower without external imposition}

2329d241-5fa5-401f-a58c-0037acaab50c.content: {Freedom is the expression of one's authentic self}, {A person is free if they can express their true identity}, {Liberty involves acting in accordance with one's inner character and nature}

6551ca03-bee6-4403-93ed-d6ec5bccd4f0.content: {Freedom is the state of being empowered to act}, {A person is free if they possess the capabilities to pursue chosen actions}, {Liberty involves having the resources and abilities necessary for action}

61fc028e-a450-4e22-9330-e1754b524339.content: {Freedom is the condition of non-domination}, {A person is free if no other has arbitrary power over them}, {Liberty involves protection from power imbalances and tyranny}

6e51dd36-e562-494a-a207-fb3c7d57a87e.content: {Freedom is the capacity for self-reflection}, {A person is free if they can critically assess their actions and beliefs}, {Liberty involves the intellectual ability to question and revise personal choices}

6bb18c82-b26c-4f53-a1d3-11c670f1aeaa.content: {Freedom is the exercise of creative agency}, {A person is free if they can innovate and create without restriction}, {Liberty involves the freedom to explore new ideas and avenues without constraint}

66f4d013-d164-44fa-8665-c94233abcf35.content: {Freedom is the ability to adapt pragmatically to circumstances}, {A person is free if they can adjust their actions to practical realities}, {Liberty involves flexibility in responding to changing environments}

bd0ac019-27f7-4e84-8392-63fcbfdebcff.summary: Distinguishing personal desires from moral capacity
bd0ac019-27f7-4e84-8392-63fcbfdebcff.content: {There is a distinction between actions driven by personal desires and those guided by moral principles.}, {Freedom as moral capacity specifically refers to the alignment of actions with moral principles, not merely with personal desires.}, {An individual acting from personal desires without moral alignment does not possess the kind of freedom described by moral capacity.}, {The theory of freedom as moral capacity focuses on the ability to enact what is morally right, which is distinct from self-directed actions not aligned with moral principles.}

ed05e319-cd08-40cd-9024-884a91520325.summary: Rejecting the necessity of subjective perspectives
ed05e319-cd08-40cd-9024-884a91520325.content: {The importance of subjective perspectives in defining freedom is overstated.}, {Moral capacity involves objective principles that transcend subjective desires or personal motivations.}, {Freedom, in this view, is about aligning with moral principles, not merely following individual inclinations without such guidance.}, {The objection misunderstands the core requirement of moral alignment by focusing on subjective impulses.}

8014f769-2d0c-47d9-8351-613a2b326026.content: {A supplementary assumption is that comprehensive motivation includes both personal desires and moral principles.}, {Under this assumption, actions can be free if they involve a harmony of subjective desires with moral principles.}, {Moral principles are integrated into the concept of comprehensive motivation which supports the theory of freedom as moral capacity.}, {This integration explains how freedom can involve personal motivation without excluding moral guidance as an essential component.}

dbab9931-abf5-4731-9d1c-aec6b51a4dde.content: {Freedom involves acting in accordance with reason}, {A person is free if they can critically evaluate their moral beliefs}, {Autonomy involves the capacity for rational self-governance}

e16fec31-3fb8-4570-9a9b-2e02226a53fc.content: {Freedom is the ability to make choices that reflect one's true self}, {A person is free if their actions express their genuine values and desires}, {Authenticity involves aligning actions with one's core identity}

c8f8ec3c-0c10-422c-8290-e11ec71cb681.content: {Freedom requires coherence between one's actions and considered moral judgments}, {A person is free if they achieve reflective equilibrium between moral principles and actions}, {Enacting freedom involves ongoing reflection and adjustment of one's moral framework}

b92a45d1-f1a7-464d-9bc3-b5910b1521ad.summary: Freedom as Coherence with Ideal Observer Standards
b92a45d1-f1a7-464d-9bc3-b5910b1521ad.content: {Freedom involves aligning actions with the standards an ideal observer would endorse}, {A person is free if their actions could be justified to an impartial and fully informed viewpoint}, {Moral capacity involves acting in ways that withstand ideal scrutiny}

7386b024-2f48-4ce4-9a34-cb783cba0c9f.content: {Freedom is the harmonious integration of desires, beliefs, and moral principles}, {A person is free if they achieve internal coherence among their motivational states}, {Liberty involves the ability to integrate conflicting elements of the self}

0c0d21ca-2e13-4bf4-a27b-6c86828659b7.summary: Distinguishing moral capacity from moral infallibility
0c0d21ca-2e13-4bf4-a27b-6c86828659b7.content: {Having the capacity to align actions with moral principles does not imply infallible moral understanding}, {Freedom as moral capacity requires the ability to act according to one's own moral understanding, not that this understanding is necessarily correct by broader societal standards}, {Errors in moral understanding do not negate the capacity for freedom but signify the complexity of moral discernment}

e6b1aeef-4f9c-4a6d-8c60-cc9d2e7cc6b6.summary: Differentiating between personal and societal moral standards
e6b1aeef-4f9c-4a6d-8c60-cc9d2e7cc6b6.content: {Freedom as moral capacity concerns personal moral understanding rather than societal or cultural standards}, {Individuals may exercise freedom within their own moral framework even if it conflicts with what is considered moral by others}, {Variation between personal and societal moral norms reflects diverse interpretations of morality, not a lack of freedom}

e7179405-3228-47b3-aafa-46697dbcddfb.summary: Adding a supplementary assumption of moral growth
e7179405-3228-47b3-aafa-46697dbcddfb.content: {Freedom as moral capacity includes an inherent orientation towards moral growth and refinement}, {Mistakes in moral judgment are part of the process of developing a more accurate moral understanding}, {The capacity to align actions with moral principles entails a dynamic, evolving comprehension of what is right}

94be05fc-de3a-44e0-b893-4107a05de91e.content: {Freedom is having the genuine ability to achieve goals}, {A person is free if they have access to numerous options that provide meaningful or desirable outcomes}, {Liberty requires the removal of barriers to realizing one's projects that are significant to the person}

4ca33cb0-9c7a-4429-ab22-1377dfee0004.content: {Freedom is having the genuine ability to achieve personally valued goals}, {A person is free if they have access to numerous options that align with their autonomous desires}, {Liberty requires the removal of barriers to freely choosing among options that are self-endorsed}

2b436a7e-8327-4451-8927-9935770663e7.content: {Freedom is having the genuine ability to achieve goals without coercion}, {A person is free if they have access to numerous options not influenced by external coercive forces}, {Liberty requires the removal of barriers imposed by others that constrain personal choice}

2fbd6107-4aa0-4181-b795-2b88dbdf7c86.content: {Freedom is having the genuine ability to make effective decisions toward achieving one's goals}, {A person is free if their options enable effective and informed decision-making}, {Liberty requires the removal of informational and psychological barriers that hinder decision-making}

a5d11f68-544f-4eb0-be2d-658a56c2e1ed.content: {Freedom is having the genuine ability to achieve goals through developed capabilities}, {A person is free if they have nurtured capabilities to select outcomes of real significance to them}, {Liberty requires the enhancement of personal capabilities to overcome external obstacles}

187bac4e-7a4c-423c-9f88-7405fa124d19.summary: Distinction between choice quantity and choice quality
187bac4e-7a4c-423c-9f88-7405fa124d19.content: {There is a distinction between the quantity of choices and the quality of those choices}, {Freedom as an opportunity concept concerns the quality of options as enabling genuine opportunities}, {A person is not genuinely free if the options are harmful or undesirable because these do not constitute real opportunities}, {The intuitive judgment that one is unfree in the scenario can be explained by understanding freedom as having valuable or meaningful options}

c85f8952-7a11-4c28-bd9d-47899167406e.summary: Rejection of the intuition about harmful options
c85f8952-7a11-4c28-bd9d-47899167406e.content: {It is mistaken to think that having numerous harmful or undesirable options undermines freedom itself}, {Freedom as the genuine ability to achieve goals is not diminished when faced with undesirable options if one still has the ability to choose without external coercion}, {The presence of options, even if harmful, does not by itself negate the presence of freedom as an opportunity}

3c7f8e66-9c8e-46ec-9d5d-797c12522253.summary: Supplementary assumption about external and internal barriers
3c7f8e66-9c8e-46ec-9d5d-797c12522253.content: {Freedom includes removing both external barriers and empowering individuals internally to make meaningful choices}, {The scenario lacks real freedom due to the internal conditions that make all options undesirable, not the number of options per se}, {Introducing a supplementary assumption that freedom involves resources to evaluate and pursue valuable options explains the diminishment of freedom in the scenario}

eceb4d0f-d719-4cff-98ef-6a8aa542cf41.content: {Freedom requires the ability to achieve goals}, {To be free, a person must have access to numerous options}, {A person is free only if their choices are independent of manipulation or coercion}, {Liberty requires the removal of barriers to realizing one's projects}
